Proposal title: Ross Amory – Q4Bio: Quantum Computing for Covalent Inhibitors
Abstract: Covalent inhibitors have emerged as a powerful class of therapeutics due to their high potency and enhanced specificity to drug targets. Their design remains challenging because covalent bond formation involves complex electronic rearrangements and rare reactive events that are difficult to capture using classical simulation approaches. In this work, we present a quantum-enhanced computational framework for modeling covalent inhibition mechanisms that integrates a novel quantum-enhanced DFT functional into existing multiscale molecular simulation methods, such as quantum mechanical/ molecular mechanics (QM/MM) umbrella sampling simulations. Reactive regions encompassing the inhibitor warhead and target nucleophile are treated at the quantum level, while the surrounding protein and solvent environment are described using molecular mechanics, enabling an accurate yet computationally tractable representation of the system.To characterize the free-energy landscape of covalent bond formation, we employ QM/MM umbrella sampling along carefully chosen reaction coordinates that describe bond formation and proton transfer events. Quantum computing is leveraged to solve the underlying electronic structure problem for the QM region, providing improved treatment of strongly correlated electronic states encountered along the reaction pathway. The resulting free-energy profiles yield activation barriers and relative binding free energies that are crucial for predicting the potency of any new drug candidates.We discuss the current “state-of-the-art“ in quantum simulation of molecular systems, and discuss the current limitations that are holding back the frontier of quantum computations. We also propose a novel method for reducing circuit complexity, which could allow for more accurate simulations on current noisy intermediate scale quantum (NISQ) devices.

Proposal title: Victor Naden Robinson – Mapping the Frenkel and Widom lines in Methane with foundational model: MACE- OFF-24
Abstract:
The physics governing the evolution from gas to liquid to close-packed liquids has long been debated, yet recently more physical observables have been realized along these thermodynamic paths[1]. We present molecular dynamics simulations of pure methane across a broad range of pressures and temperatures spanning the supercritical regime, with the aim of characterising dynamical crossovers beyond the critical point. Using a machine-learning interatomic potential, MACE-OFF-24[2], we generate long, well-equilibrated trajectories that enable robust analysis of transport properties as a function of pressure and temperature. The self-diffusion coefficient exhibits distinct changes in pressure dependence that are consistent with two separate supercritical boundaries: a low-pressure anomaly associated with Widom-line behaviour (~0.006 GPa) and a higher-pressure crossover indicative of a Frenkel-line transition (~0.07 GPa) from liquid-like to compact-liquid-like dynamics. This transition pressures are in good agreement with recent experiments[1] and diffusion coefficients become close to observed values once applying the Yeh-Hummer finite-size correction[3].

[1] Ranieri, U., Formisano, F., Gorelli, F.A. et al. Crossover from gas-like to liquid-like molecular diffusion in a simple supercritical fluid. Nat Commun 15, 4142 (2024). https://doi.org/10.1038/s41467-024-47961-7
[2] Kovács, Dávid Péter, et al. ""Mace-off: Short-range transferable machine learning force fields for organic molecules."" Journal of the American Chemical Society 147.21 (2025): 17598-17611. https://pubs.acs.org/doi/10.1021/jacs.4c07099
[3] Yeh, In-Chul, and Gerhard Hummer. ""System-size dependence of diffusion coefficients and viscosities from molecular dynamics simulations with periodic boundary conditions."" The Journal of Physical Chemistry B

Proposal title: Nils Hertl – First-principles construction of Newns-Anderson Hamiltonians for hydrogen chemistry at surfaces
Abstract:
Adsorption of atomic and molecular hydrogen on surfaces is the gateway to many important chemical processes in nature. For realistic simulations of adsorption of hydrogen atoms or molecules at metal surfaces, or light-driven desorption, accurate couplings between the gaseous particles and the substrate’s electronic states are essential. However, their acquisition and utilisation for molecular dynamics is not straightforward if one wishes to account for the spectral properties of the substrate.

Here, we present a pragmatic protocol based on the projection-operator diabatisation (POD) approach that allows the acquisition of electronic couplings between adsorbate and metallic substrates. Since the POD approach relies on partitioning the states of the total system into an adsorbate subset and a substrate subset, it has primarily been applied to weakly interacting systems, whilst its applicability to strongly interacting systems has been questioned. Here, we will present a strategy to overcome this issue and apply our workflow to strongly interacting systems, i.e., atomic hydrogen adsorbed on metal surfaces. We show that we can verify the validity of this projection by reconstructing the projected density of states of the adsorbate and extracting electron-tunnelling rates. We further connect these electronic couplings to vibrational relaxation rates due to electron-hole pair (ehp) excitation. This allows us to compare our acquired results to pump-probe experiments} and computational reference data acquired from density functional theory based time-dependent perturbation theory. 

Finally, we outline how this approach allows for the construction of Newns-Anderson Hamiltonians, the standard model in gas-surface dynamics, to describe the interaction of a single adsorbate state with a continuum of metal states.

Proposal title: Victor Naden Robinson – Crystal structure prediction with foundational models: Application to lead phosphate
Abstract:
Crystal structure prediction (CSP) depends on reliable energy evaluations of potential
energy surfaces for a given material. Conventional DFT methods are recently being
replaced machine-learned potentials and now even foundational models, allowing for
rapid exploration of these complex energetic landscapes. However, due to the unphysical
and anti-chemical nature of many structures that are generated for CSP, not all
foundational models are suitable for such workflows. Here, we apply a foundational-
model-based CSP workflow to the lead phosphate system, we are able to recover and
confirm the ground state structure for Pb3(PO4)2 is a rarely observed C2/c structure (we
name ɣ), as opposed to another C2/c structure (ɑ) commonly found at room
temperature. Structure searching results for the Pb3(PO4)2 composition confirm that
these are the lowest energy phases. Notably, the ɑ phase was found more frequently in
searches than the rarely observed (ɣ) phase, similar to its experimental occurrence where
it has only been observed once [1].

[1] E.L. Belokoneva, O.A. Gurbanova, O.V. Dimitrova, Zhurnal Neorganicheskoi Khimii, 2000, 45, 1448

Proposal title: Connor Williamson – Machine-Learned Phase Prediction of Mixed-Halide Perovskites at Finite Temperature
Abstract:
Halide perovskites exhibit exceptional optoelectronic properties critical for the next generation of photovoltaics and energy storage. However, these properties are highly phase-dependent, and the most desirable phases are often metastable at room temperature. Predicting phase stability computationally is challenging; the regular presence of heavy atomic species in halide perovskites increases the already expensive cost of ab initio
treatments, making traditional molecular dynamics at realistic timescales computationally prohibitive.

In this work, we present a high-throughput computational workflow that utilizes Machine-Learned Force Fields (MLFFs) to map the phase space of mixed-halide perovskites at room temperature. We employ an active learning scheme to curate a robust training dataset, upon which both foundational and de novo MLFFs are trained to achieve ab initio accuracy at a fraction of the computational cost. By the utilizing this MLFF and performing finite-
temperature structural dynamics, we extract key structural descriptors to train a classification model capable of predicting the stable phase of candidate materials from a perovskites stoichiometry and other readily available data, such as ionic radii and both structural and machine-learned tolerance factors. The resulting 2D phase map provides a rapid, cost- effective tool for experimentalists to identify stable, high-performance perovskite compositions without the need for exhaustive first-principles calculations.

Proposal title: Alexander Spears – Electronic friction simulations of laser-driven hydrogen desorption from copper: Is it just thermal desorption in a hurry?
Abstract:
Ultrafast light pulses can induce energy transfer between light, electrons, and phonons at interfaces, leading to ultrafast dynamics such as light-driven hydrogen evolution from metal surfaces. 
Whether this energy transfer can drive photocatalysis through selective energy transfer into certain degrees of freedom remains an open question. 
Molecular dynamics simulations with electronic friction (MDEF) offer a quantum-classical description of electron-phonon coupling and have previously been used to model ultrafast surface dynamics. 
However, the effect of different electronic friction approximations on the final energy distributions has not been thoroughly investigated. 
We present MDEF simulations of light-driven hydrogen evolution from different copper surface facets, enabled by machine-learning surrogate models. 
For various laser fluences, we study desorption probabilities and final state distributions of desorbed molecules.
Our results reveal that the choice of electronic friction approximation significantly affects desorption probabilities. 
However, the magnitude and nature of friction do not seem to affect the final vibrational, rotational, and translational energy distribution of molecular adsorbates. Within the electronic friction approximation, only the shape of the energy landscape determines these properties and no selective energy transfer occurs. This suggests that thermal and laser-driven desorption may yield similar outcomes.

Proposal title: Saffron Luxford – Developing GRACE Machine Learning Force Fields for Hafnium Zirconium Oxide Ferroelectric Simulations
Abstract:
"Hafnium zirconium oxide (HZO) is a promising ferroelectric material for next-generation memory devices, but understanding its atomic-scale behaviour requires simulations that are currently too computationally expensive with traditional density functional theory (DFT) methods. The complex interplay between oxygen vacancies and ferroelectric polarisation in HZO demands large-scale molecular dynamics simulations spanning thousands of atoms and nanosecond timescales well beyond the reach of standard ab initio approaches.

This work proposes developing machine learned force fields using the GRACE framework to enable efficient, accurate simulations of HZO systems. The approach involves training GRACE models on DFT datasets that capture key HZO configurations, including pristine orthorhombic structures and oxygen-deficient systems with varying vacancy concentrations. The goal is to achieve near-DFT accuracy whilst providing the computational speedup necessary for device-scale simulations. The successful development of accurate GRACE force fields for HZO would enable molecular dynamics studies of larger systems over longer timescales, providing insights into vacancy-induced dynamics and polarisation stability that are crucial for optimising HZO-based devices."

Proposal title: Shay Chaudhuri – Calculating Covalent Inhibition Using Quantum Chemistry, Hybrid QM/MM and Quantum Computing
Abstract: Covalent drug design presents a challenging frontier for conventional computational resources. The system size typically needed to study ligand-protein binding limits the applicability of high-level ab initio methods, and concessions must be made via various approximations. This bottleneck limits progress in the burgeoning field of covalent drug design. We have used high-level quantum chemistry calculations to characterise the addition of methanethiolate to various Michael acceptors and investigated the structural, energetic, and electronic properties of the resulting enolates, as well as their reaction profiles. To assess the influence of the receptor protein on the binding thermodynamics, we are studying covalent inhibitors in complex with the protein CDK12 using hybrid QM/MM calculations. The most forward-looking part of our work is the opportunity to use quantum computing to model molecular interactions for drug discovery, and we are working on a novel pathway to quantum-enhanced computations of covalent inhibitors on near-term quantum devices.

Proposal title: Ross Amory – Quantum Computing for Quantum Chemistry
Abstract:
Classical computers struggle with the inherent complexity of simulating quantum systems, especially in chemistry, where capturing phenomena such as electron correlation is challenging using classical approaches. This presentation investigates how quantum computing can be used to address some of the limitations of classical algorithms and capture traditionally difficult-to-simulate phenomena such as electron correlation.
We focus on how quantum algorithms can tackle fundamental problems in quantum chemistry, such as determining accurate ground state energies and modelling reaction dynamics. The discussion includes practical hurdles that need to be overcome in order for the field to become useful. Examples of current research employing techniques such as variational quantum algorithms on near-term quantum hardware will also be discussed to provide an insight into the direction in which the field is currently evolving.

Proposal title: Tom Irons – Discovery of Novel Lanthanide Colour Centres in Lanthanum Oxyhalide 2D Materials for Quantum Technologies
Abstract: Solid-state colour centres—optically active spin defects in wide bandgap semiconductors—are a promising platform for qubits, the building blocks of quantum technologies; however, challenges remain to their wider application, including low quantum coherence and difficulties engineering spin defects in different semiconductor hosts. Lanthanide colour centres hold particular promise for the development of spin qubits since their partially occupied 4f subshells are highly shielded from environmental perturbations, potentially offering high quantum coherence. In this work, we investigate a novel class of colour centre, lanthanide substitutional defects in the lanthanum oxyhalide (LaOX) materials. The lanthanum oxyhalides LaOCl and LaOBr are wide bandgap 2D semiconductors stable at room temperature and transparent to visible light, ideal properties as semiconductor hosts for colour centres. We deploy a combination of advanced density functional theory (DFT) and multiconfigurational wavefunction methodology to model the electronic, optical, and magnetic properties lanthanide substitutional defects in LaOCl and LaOBr, identifying equilibrium structures corresponding to their most stable electronic charge and spin states through solid-state DFT. We further employ multireference and quasi-degenerate perturbation theories on the local defect environments, essential for accurately representing the strongly correlated ground and excited electronic states of lanthanides, to evaluate their zero-phonon lines and zero-field splitting parameters to predict colour centres with optical activity at telecom-band wavelengths and those for which their spin states may be coherently manipulated via microwave radiation. The discovery of lanthanide colour centres satisfying these criteria is expected to be a significant breakthrough in the search for novel spin qubits with high coherence, enabling the development of next-generation quantum technologies.

Proposal title: Shay Chaudhuri: Multiplet structure of chromium(III) dopants in wide band gap materials
Abstract: Transition metal doping is commonly used for altering the properties of solid-state materials to suit applications in science and technology. Partially filled d-shells of transition metal atoms lead to electronic states with diverse spatial and spin symmetries. Chromium(III) cations have shown great potential for designing laser materials and, more recently, for developing spin qubits in quantum applications. They also represent an intriguing class of chemical systems with strongly correlated multi-reference excited states, due to the d³ electron configuration. These states are difficult to describe accurately using single-reference quantum chemical methods such as density functional theory (DFT), the most commonly used method to study the electronic structures of solid-state systems. Recently, the periodic effective Hamiltonian of crystal field (pEHCF) method has been shown to overcome some limitations arising in the calculations of excited d-states. In this work, we assess the suitability of DFT and pEHCF to calculate the electronic structure and d-d excitations of chromium(III) dopants in wide band gap host materials. The results will aid computational development of novel transition metal-doped materials and provide a deeper understanding of the complex nature of transition metal dopants in solids.

Proposal title: Connor Williamson – Screening the stability and optoelectronic properties of mixed halide perovskites at finite temperatures
Abstract:
"Mixed halide perovskites present a wide compositional space for
engineering functional semiconducting properties that can be
leveraged in optoelectronic devices including photovoltaics, light
emitting-diodes and coherent light sources. While the stability and
properties of single perovskites have been well-mapped, mixed
perovskites present the challenge of complex tolerance factors and
emergent properties from mixing in a combinatorially large phase
space. Here, we utilise machine learned force fields to
computationally screen 1000’s of mixed halide perovskites for
formability and thermodynamic and dynamic stability. From this, we
reveal patterns in combined octahedral tilts and rotations compared
to unmixed phases. We further predict trends in emission spectra of
stable mixed systems at finite temperatures. We anticipate that this
data-driven approach will accelerate the discovery and design of
next-generation perovskite materials for the realisation of more
efficient and stable optoelectronic technologies."

Proposal title: Liz Hawkins – layered lanthanum oxyhalides for high k applications
Abstract:
"Silicon-based dielectrics are reaching scaling limits in semiconductor microelectronics. As transistors shrink to the atomic scale, quantum tunnelling and leakage currents become significant challenges, limiting further miniaturisation. New materials with superior properties are required to overcome this bottleneck. 

Lanthanum oxyhalides (LaOX, X = F, Cl, Br, I) have recently been identified as promising materials due to their high dielectric constant (k), wide bandgap and chemical stability. As layered van der Waals materials (vdW), they are able to retain these properties even at low dimensions.

This poster explores the structural, electronic and dielectric properties of LaOX using density functional theory (DFT). By first understanding how well density functional approximations (DFA’s) capture the properties of LaOX, we will be able to use DFT to further explore its applications in low-power devices and quantum technologies. "

Proposal title: Caitlin Lewis – Quantum Methods to Study Exciton Dynamics
Abstract: Could quantum mechanics play a role in biological processes, such as photosynthesis? This presentation explores the quantum explanation for energy transport between chromophores in biological systems. Excitons, which are bound electron-hole pairs, may facilitate this energy transfer. I will present a method for studying exciton dynamics starting with tubulin, a protein with important biological roles related to structure, and explain why this problem is well-suited for quantum computing. Currently, only classical computing methods have been applied in this study. However, quantum computing offers a promising avenue for overcoming computational limitations, potentially enabling more accurate and efficient simulations of larger exciton systems in biological contexts.

Proposal title: Henry Snowden – First-principles-derived Boltzmann transport study of hot electron generation efficiency in antenna-reactor photocatalysts
Abstract: Bimetallic antenna-reactor nanoclusters are a promising material class for photocatalytic applications due to their ability to combine the optical absorption efficiency of a plasmonic metal and the reactivity of a transition-metal catalyst. These materials come in many different structures relating to the arrangement of the antenna and reactor components. Photocatalytic efficiency is determined by the hot carrier concentration created upon laser excitation and the ability to transfer such carriers to the reactant. Their prediction requires the ability so simulate non-equilibrium laser-driven electron dynamics and the interplay of electrons, phonons, and photons. Here, we employ a first-principles-parametrised Boltzmann transport method called AthEM [arXiv: 2503.09479], able to capture time- and space-resolved non-equilibrium electron populations in differing antenna-reactor structures. We compare the effective temperatures, electron distributions and phonon temperatures at the surface of the reactor material to support the design of  catalyst geometries that maximize hot carrier generation.

Proposal title: Valdas Vitartas – Bridging electronic structure and machine learning at the operator level
Abstract: The computational cost associated with first-principles materials simulations has motivated the progress of data-driven algorithms, such as machine learning (ML) interatomic potentials trained on electronic structure (ES) data. While such models can reproduce reference energies at a fraction of the cost, they typically cannot predict electronic properties. Alternatively, one can learn intermediate quantities from ES calculations, such as the self-consistent Hamiltonian from density functional theory. This yields ML models with stronger physics-based inductive bias and retained electronic degrees of freedom, enabling the prediction of electronic properties such as the band structure. However, tighter coupling between ES and ML necessitates the development of new data pipelines. This talk will introduce Quoll.jl, a julia package that can process and transfer quantum operator data between ES and ML codes while accounting for differing sparsity formats and spherical harmonics conventions. The code will be showcased by removing core states from bulk gold Hamiltonians generated with the FHI-aims ES package before converting them to a format compatible with the MACE-H ML model. To demonstrate the capability in the opposite direction, ML-predicted Hamiltonians will be passed back to FHI-aims for postprocessing, bypassing self-consistent-field iterations.

Proposal title: Saffron Luxford – Ferroelectric Hf₁₋ₓZrₓO₂ Thin Films: A Materials Challenge for Machine- Learned Interatomic Potentials
Abstract:
Ferroelectric hafnia-based thin films have emerged as promising materials for nanoscale non-volatile memory and logic applications, combining ferroelectric behaviour with compatibility with silicon technology. Despite extensive experimental and theoretical effort, the microscopic origins of ferroelectricity in Hf₁₋ₓZrₓO₂ (HZO) remain incompletely understood. This is thought to be due to the complex interplay between composition, epitaxial strain, finite-size effects, interfacial chemistry, and defect formation, all of which influence the relative stability of closely competing polymorphs. Density functional theory (DFT) has provided valuable atomistic insight into these mechanisms, but its high computational cost limits simulations to relatively small system sizes. As a result, many phenomena central to achieving reliable ferroelectricity thin-film devices, such as realistic heterointerfaces,
extended defects, domain structures, and strain gradients, remain difficult to
access directly. Machine-learned Force Fields (MLFFs) offer a promising route to
bridge this gap, but their application to HZO poses significant challenges due to
the material’s narrow energy landscape, and sensitivity to charged defects.
In this work, we develop MACE-based interatomic potentials for HZO trained on
VASP DFT configurations at the PBE level of theory. We demonstrate that MACE
models accurately reproduce structural parameters from geometry
optimizations, enabling rapid exploration of composition-strain-structure
relationships.
Our work demonstrates the potential of machine-learned force fields to
accelerate exploration of structure-property relationships in complex oxide
ferroelectrics, providing a pathway to computational screening at scales beyond
the reach of conventional DFT while targeting quantitative accuracy for both
structural and electronic descriptors.

Proposal title: Mariia Radova: Fine-tuning foundation models of materials interatomic potentials with frozen transfer learning
Abstract: Machine-learned interatomic potentials are revolutionising atomistic materials simulations by providing accurate and scalable predictions within the scope covered by the training data. However, generation of an accurate and robust training data set remains a challenge, often requiring thousands of first-principles calculations to achieve high accuracy. Foundation models have started to emerge with the ambition to create universally applicable potentials across a wide range of materials. While foundation models can be robust and transferable, they do not yet achieve the accuracy required to predict reaction barriers, phase transitions, and material stability. This work demonstrates that foundation model potentials can reach chemical accuracy when fine-tuned using transfer learning with partially frozen weights and biases. For two challenging datasets on reactive chemistry at surfaces and stability and elastic properties of tertiary alloys, we show that frozen transfer learning with 10–20% of the data (hundreds of datapoints) achieves similar accuracies to models trained from scratch (on thousands of datapoints). Moreover, we show that an equally accurate, but significantly more efficient surrogate model can be built using the transfer learned potential as the ground truth. In combination, we present a simulation workflow for machine learning potentials that improves data efficiency and computational efficiency.

Proposal title: Shirui Wang – Fine-tuning universal force fields for rapid and accurate lattice thermal conductivity
Abstract: Lattice thermal conductivity (κl) is a fundamental materials property that is vital for applications such thermoelectrics and power electronics. Over recent decades, predicting lattice thermal conductivity has primarily relied on classical molecular dynamics or first-principles calculations. However, these methods often suffer from insufficient accuracy or high computational costs. Recent advancements in universal machine learning models for materials offer a promising solution to these limitations. In this study, we conducted extensive calculations of κl using three universal models and compared their performance against ab initio calculations for 25 zincblende and wurtzite compounds. Our findings indicate that all off-the-shelf models consistently underpredict phonon frequencies and thermal conductivity. However, we demonstrate that this phonon softening can be effectively addressed by fine-tuning with small amounts of additional data. In particular, the fine-tuned MACE-MP-0 model displays remarkable accuracy while requiring several orders of magnitude less computational cost than first-principles calculations. Our approach has the potential to significantly accelerate the materials discovery process
